comment_text: I don't mean to rain on Elon's parade, but he's going to have mars colonized by extremely wealthy people so they'll escape paying taxes, and grow richer by aquiring resources and survive major apocalypses while we on Earth suffer.

Well, I hate to crash the party, but there are many technological barriers between the BFR and Mars. First of all, the issue of returning to Earth has never been addressed by SpaceX to enough detail to actually accomplish it. Contrary to popular opinion, Wernher von Braun was actually the first person to address the idea of landing rockets for use in Mars travel, and NASA has been toying with the idea ever since. You see, landing a rocket on Earth after launching it from earth is one thing. The 4 phase dispersion/correction algorithm necessary to accomplish this was finished in the last decade, and is used to above 60% reliability by SpaceX. But launching a rocket from Mars and landing it on Earth is a different matter entirely. Not that it is at all impossible, but it will require a long series of experimentation with autonomous deep space navigation systems, in addition to other problems, like radiation shielding, thermal breakdown, and TEI injection from millions of miles away. Falcon X missed their trajectory with the Tesla roadster from low earth orbit, and they will have to make some serious progress to be able to "shoot accurately" from 60 million miles away. Anyway, I think that they can make it to Mars, but not by 2022.

Hi, I love how the BFS is refuelled by a few BFTankers and then shoots off to Mars. But I'm wondering if we really wanted to get the trip time down if it's possible to strap a booster on to the fully refuelled BFS? Booster burns, gets the BFS up to a certain speed, and hopefully the booster has enough fuel left to land on Mars for re-use (or park in orbit for refuelling from BFTankers and reuse). The BFS then disconnects after the booster burn and fires its own engines for an even faster transit. Would the BFS then need to be 'caught' and decelerated the other end by a second space-booster, or would aerobraking and its own fuel let it land on Mars? Anyone run the math on this?

One thing Musk didn't mention. perhaps very smartly, is that the BFR first stage could conceivably send up a massive dedicated payload that was NOT the BFS into Earth orbit. With a dry weight of 85 tons, that means you could send up that much more payload. So SpaceX could send up a 200+ ton payload to LEO with ease, if they retooled and kept the second stage integral.

Which means... Space Hotels become even more cost effective :-) Wouldn't that be interesting? If one of the modes of income was SpaceX hotels? Or maybe the Hyatt Regency LEO? Point being, yes I know cost per kilogram would be higher in this case, however the size of payload would be massively increased, and now.. all of a sudden, you can send up prefab space hotels in one or two shots, saving millions on construction, design and material costs.

In other words, you could make the things from aluminum and composites instead of exotic materials, and make up more than the payload cost differential in construction and material costs.

If SpaceX succeeds with these plans, even with 2 to 4 year slip in timeframe, SpaceX will be able to make bigger BFR.  Frankly, my plan was to make a vastly larger diameter spacecraft that from a top view looks a bit like a hollow tube.  The individual booster rockets would then be a ring at the bottom of the tube, and of course the top would be tapered to a sharpish point to reduce drag, enhance stability, and implement control surfaces.  Also, 6~8 thin sections (almost like thin blades) would connect the outer ring to a small central hub.  In space, the craft can spin around the central hub to create artificial gravity in the outer tube (perhaps 0.20G to 0.50G, probably not 1.00G).

Elon seems to calculate the fastest physically possible path to his goal, publicly shoot for a notch below that, then perform one to three notches lower yet. This time, there are well-defined notches — optimal launch windows to Mars. If we figure the unmanned mission slips by one and the manned one by an additional two, we're at 2030.

In the meantime, lessons will be learned, the plan will be improved, doubters will become convinced. I think Earth-to-Earth passenger service, followed by Earth-Moon shuttling — all on the BFR — should begin as early as possible, to prove it out and find the flaws.

The biggest innovation since last year is the move to a single product line, cannibalizing the current hardware. This plan means means far fewer things to develop, test, and build. That should improve profitability and, more importantly, the ability to live up to Elon's aspirational pace.

Seems like the biggest issue with a proposed mars mission using this system is the fuel required to ascend from Mars and achieve martian orbit (and an Earth return trajectory.)   Elon's plan requires the ability to refuel on mars, and so far they've fairly glossed over how they plan to do that beyond saying: the stuff we need to make fuel is there.  Sure, but with what technology?  So far all we've landed on Mars is a few probes and rovers...that's a far cry from strip-mining water ice to make rocket fuel.  It seems like any first mission will have to be accomplished through the use of a quite a few support launches.  Even then we're talking about refueling on the Martian surface.  So they'll need to design a system for that.  And those are just a few fundamental issues that will have to be worked out at the same time they're prepping this monstrous spacecraft.  It's a lot of problems to solve in just a few years.  I think they're all solvable and I'm really excited by what SpaceX is doing, and I think this is overall a good plan.  But there's a lot.

A few questions:
What size vehicle (vehicle & payload) could be air launched to earth orbit? Like the Pegasus of Orbital Launch Services. What fixed wing plane could maximize that approach? (Antonov An-225 Mriya??) Would Earth to orbit be better utilized with smaller components for orbital assembly of BFR? All would have the "reusability" design.
Would high altitude launch be viable with a specifically designed aircraft to deliver the rocket to a desired altitude. Atmosphere flight (wings etc) Reducing the demands of a ground based first stage.
Same question for balloon platform launch.
Comparing surface to orbit launches, what would be configuration changes for the different atmospheres and gravity for the current "ground" launches? Earth - moon - Mars. i.e. Earth has densest atmosphere and highest gravity. Moon the least of both. Mars would be closer to Earth but time and distance issues for resources and contingency.
And similar space launches for Earth - moon - Mars orbits?
It seems that each initiation site would have significant differences for optimal performance.
For Earth based launches, where would the best possible launch site be? Equator - high - altitude - ocean barge - etc.??

It could be that they want to bake in the ability to do thurst powered turning so that if one or more of the engines fails they can just up the thrust on the others, this could also be that running the engines at full tilt would hurt there usability so you get a two for one you both get the ability to reuse the engines much more and it's safer.

Although not by much considering if you did have to fall back over driving other engines to make up for the loss of some engines you would likely pick up an oscillation which would destroy the craft, but it's better than nothing and when working with 32 engines and if it is to be believed passenger flights you will need the fallback.

Although if you are just worried about a single engine failure thrust vectoring should be enough although as said if they are only using them at half thrust they could lose 1/4 the engines on the same side and still be fine as long as you can stop the craft from picking up a large oscillation, and as long as the loss of engines was evenly distributed you could lose upto half the engines, and ontop thrust vectoring and likely you could lose a third of you engines on one side, but you wouldn't be able to turn that was if you has a little extra authority to insensate a roll you could simply roll until you could turn the way you needed to.

But you would need some pretty well programmed software and the ability to individually change the thrust on each engine very quickly, although to allow passenger flights it will be likely that is what will need to be done because at that point you have at least negated the risk of engine failure being the most likely cause of a loss of the craft, although there are still other problems but those are simple by comparison to being able to individually change thrust on each engine and to be able to have the fine control in thrust output to at least 100 different thrust levels and probably you would need 1000 levels of thrust which would need to be able to be changed within just below a millisecond to stop the craft picking up an oscillation.

Although if you lost even 4 of your engines on one side in one go the instant stress on the craft would break it apart.

I think it is economically infeasible. Musk admits that going to Mars will need massive subsidies from other SpaceX operations. He will need to over-charge his launch customers to fund the development of BFR. That means his competition has a window in which to steal his business. Competitors who focus on reusability without grandiose future plans can undercut SpaceX. SpaceX will have to drop their price, thus lose the margin that would have funded Mars, or lose all their customers which would also not allow Mars funding.

Musk has got to be more patient. He needs to concentrate on dropping LEO launch cost as low as possible. Others can develop other space activities, let them compete and take risks on their dime. In 20-30 years there aught to be a thriving space economy that can make building interplanetary craft in space cheap and easy. SpaceX needs to follow where the money is. For the foreseeable future the money is in services for Earth: communication, Earth observation, clean energy, science.

If SpaceX shoots for Mars right now they'll burn through piles of money, probably lose loads of customers and have a half-baked Mars colony to show for it. His competition will have followed the money in near-space and stayed relevant.
The free market wins again

I think that it is overly optimistic to believe that full reusability and trips to mars are happening anytime soon. The successful recovery of the Falcon first stage has been demonstrated only a handful of times. A recovered first stage has been re-flown only once. So this all is far from routine. It is still experimental at this point. The savings of reusabiliy have yet to be proven.The question really is: how reusable? What will the REAL costs be? This has to take into account recovery failure rate (10%? 30%?), the costs of refurbishment, the number of times the engines can be reused. Remember, the space shuttle main engines had to be completely rebuilt after each use. The 'airliner analogy' is deceptive. Going into space is a vastly different proposition from flying place to place on earth. In order to reach earth orbit, the fuel is at least 80% of the take off weight. The engines must be about a 1000 times more powerful than an airliner engine of the same weight. Items such as the engines and the vehicle structure are under many times the stress of these components in  aircraft. It would be NICE if rockets were really reusable, costs to orbit were a  fraction of today's cost, if the first trip to mars were  to happen before today's children are middle-aged.
